element.name: TButtonLayout
element.short: A set of constants to define the position of a glyph on a button.

element.name: TButtonState
element.short: A set of constants to define the state of a SpeedButton.

element.name: TCustomButton
element.short: The ancestor class for TButton
element.descr: TCustomButton is the ancestor for TButton. If you want to define your own button class, you should use this class to derive it from.

element.name: TCustomButton.Create
element.short: Creates a new instance of the TCustomButton class
element.descr:
If you drop a component on the form editor you don´t need to add code to explicitly create it. The component is automatically created together with the the form, and destroyed when the form is destroyed.
However, if you create the component by code don´t forget to free it when it is no longer needed.
Constructors allocate memory and system resources needed by the object. They also call the constructor of any sub-objects present in the class.

element.name: TButton
element.short: The most basic button component
element.descr: Button: Base type for all Buttons. A push button control. The user pushes a button (eg selects it with the mouse cursor and clicks the mouse) to start an action.

element.name: TButton.Click
element.short: Click, calling this method will invoke the OnClick event of the button
element.descr: If you want to programmatically Click on a button you can call its Click method. This will have the same effect as a user clicking on the button.

element.name: TButton.Action
element.short: The action executed when the user clicks the button.
element.descr: If you assign an action from an ActionList to a TButton.Action the correspondig execute-method is assigned to the OnClick event of the button. Assigning a action sets other properties of the button as well, like Enabled and Caption.

element.name: TButton.Align
element.descr:
Possible values fo Allign are:
alTop: Places the control at the top, using the full clientwidth of its parent control.
alBottom: Places the control at the bottom, using the full clientwidth of its parent control.
alLeft: Places the control at the left side of its parent and uses the available height between any top or bottom alligned controls.
alRight: Like alLeft but on the right side of the parent control.
alNone: The control can be placed anywhere on the parent control.
alClient: The control takes al available space on parent control next to controls aligned to the top, bottom, right or left.

element.name: TButton.Anchors
element.short: Anchors are used to keep a button on a defined distance to certain borders of the parent control.
element.descr:
Anchors can be used to keep control at a certain distance from a side of its parent control, when the parent control is resized.
For instance setting Anchors to [akBottom, akRight] will keep the control at a constant distance to the bottom right corner.

element.name: TButton.AutoSize
element.short: Autosize in TButton has no function.
element.descr: If this property is set to true, the control will automatically adapt its size to be able to accomodate its content. This property is not used in Buttons.

element.name: TButton.BorderSpacing
element.short: Borderspacing ????

element.name: TButton.Cancel
element.short: Setting this property will make the OnClick event executed when the user hits ESC.
element.descr: Setting this property to true, will have the effect that when the user hits ESC this button is Clicked. Usually the Button which reacts to ESC sets the ModalResult of the form to mrCancel.

element.name: TButton.Caption
element.short: Sets the text displayed on the button.

element.name: TButton.Constraints
element.short: Constraints can be used to give a control certain minimum and or maximum dimensions.
element.descr: Sets the minimum and maximum sizes for a control. If a control is resized the new dimensions are allways within the ranges given here. You should take care when setting these options that they do not conflict with the Anchors en Allign settings.

element.name: TButton.Default
element.short: Setting this property will make the OnClick event executed when the user hits ENTER
element.descr: Defines if a button is the default on a form. That is, pressing enter will execute its onClick wether the control has focus or not!

element.name: TButton.Enabled
element.short: Determines if the button reacts to a click.
element.descr: Setting this property determines if the control can be used. If Enabled is false a button cannot be clicked. Setting the Enabled property to false also makes its appearance grayed. If an Action has been assigned to the button and this action is disabled then the enabled property is set to false as well.

element.name: TButton.Font
element.short: Font is used to set the font of the caption of the Button.
element.descr: Font is used to set the font of the caption of the Button.

element.name: TButton.ModalResult
element.short: If the button gets clicked, the ModalResult of the form will be set to this value.
element.descr: Setting ModalResult of a button makes closing a form easy. Just set this property to a value different from mrNone and a click on this button will set the modalresult of the form it is placed on to this value. Setting the ModalResult of a form will make it close.

element.name: TButton.OnClick
element.short: The OnClick event is triggered when a user clicks on the button
element.descr: The OnClick event is triggered when a user clicks on the button. It can also be invoked by calling the Click method.

element.name: TButton.OnEnter
element.short: The OnEnter event is triggered when the button gets focus.
element.descr: The OnEnter event is triggered when the button gets focus.

element.name: TButton.OnExit
element.short: The OnExit event is triggered when the button loses focus.
element.descr: The OnExit event is triggered when the button loses focus.

element.name: TButtonGlyph
element.short: A small image that can be attached to buttons
element.descr: Button Glyph: The graphics and legend on a button

element.name: TButtonGlyph.Create
element.short: Creates a new instance of the TButtonGlyph class
element.descr:
If you drop a component on the form editor you don´t need to add code to explicitly create it. The component is automatically created together with the the form, and destroyed when the form is destroyed.
However, if you create the component by code don´t forget to free it when it is no longer needed.
Constructors allocate memory and system resources needed by the object. They also call the constructor of any sub-objects present in the class.

element.name: TButtonGlyph.Destroy
element.short: Deallocates an object
element.descr:
If you call Destroy for an object witch hasn´t being initialized yet it will generate an error. Always use the Free method to deallocate objects, because it verifies if object variable doesn´t contain the value nil.
Take the following precautions when creating your own Destroy method:
* Declare Destroy with the override directive, because it is a virtual method.
* Always call 'inherited Destroy;' as the last thing on the destructor code.
* An exception may be raised on the constructor in case there is not enought memory to create an object, or something else goes wrong. If the exception is not handled inside the constructor, the object will be only partially built. In this case Destroy will be called, so your destructor must check if the resources were really allocated before disposing of them.
* Remember to call Free for all objects created on the constructor.

element.name: TBitBtnKind
element.short: A set of possible types for BitButtons.

element.name: TCustomBitBtn
element.short: The ancestor class for TBitBtn.
element.descr: TCustomBitBtn is the ancestor for TBitBtn. If you want to define your own bitbutton class, you should use this class to derive it from.

element.name: TCustomBitBtn.Create
element.short: Creates a new instance of the TCustomBitBtn class
element.descr:
If you drop a component on the form editor you don´t need to add code to explicitly create it. The component is automatically created together with the the form, and destroyed when the form is destroyed.
However, if you create the component by code don´t forget to free it when it is no longer needed.
Constructors allocate memory and system resources needed by the object. They also call the constructor of any sub-objects present in the class.

element.name: TCustomBitBtn.Destroy
element.short: Deallocates an object
element.descr:
If you call Destroy for an object witch hasn´t being initialized yet it will generate an error. Always use the Free method to deallocate objects, because it verifies if object variable doesn´t contain the value nil.
Take the following precautions when creating your own Destroy method:
* Declare Destroy with the override directive, because it is a virtual method.
* Always call 'inherited Destroy;' as the last thing on the destructor code.
* An exception may be raised on the constructor in case there is not enought memory to create an object, or something else goes wrong. If the exception is not handled inside the constructor, the object will be only partially built. In this case Destroy will be called, so your destructor must check if the resources were really allocated before disposing of them.
* Remember to call Free for all objects created on the constructor.

element.name: TBitBtn
element.short: A Button with a small image attached
element.descr: Bit Button: a push button control on a toolbar causing a particular action to be executed. It often displays a glyph or small graphic to denote its function.

element.name: TBitBtn.Action
element.short: The action executed when the user clicks the button.
element.descr: If you assign an action from an ActionList to a TBitBtn.Action the correspondig execute-method is assigned to the OnClick event of the button. Assigning a action sets other properties of the button as well, like Enabled and Caption.

element.name: TBitBtn.Align
element.short: Is used to allign a bitbutton to a border of a parent control.
element.descr:
Align is used to align a control to a border of a parent control, even if the parent control is resized.
Possible values fo Allign are:
alTop: Places the control at the top, using the full clientwidth of its parent control.
alBottom: Places the control at the bottom, using the full clientwidth of its parent control.
alLeft: Places the control at the left side of its parent and uses the available height between any top or bottom alligned controls.
alRight: Like alLeft but on the right side of the parent control.
alNone: The control can be placed anywhere on the parent control.
alClient: The control takes al available space on parent control next to controls aligned to the top, bottom, right or left.

element.name: TBitBtn.Anchors
element.short: Anchors are used to keep a button on a defined distance to certain borders of the parent control.
element.descr:
Anchors can be used to keep control at a certain distance from a side of its parent control, when the parent control is resized.
For instance setting Anchors to [akBottom, akRight] will keep the control at a constant distance to the bottom right corner.

element.name: TBitBtn.Cancel
element.short: Setting this property will make the OnClick event executed when the user hits ESC.
element.descr: Setting this property to true, will have the effect that when the user hits ESC this button is Clicked. Usually the Button which reacts to ESC sets the ModalResult of the form to mrCancel.

element.name: TBitBtn.Caption
element.short: Sets the text displayed on the button.

element.name: TBitBtn.Constraints
element.short: Used to give a control certain minimum and or maximum dimensions.
element.descr: Sets the minimum and maximum sizes for a control. If a control is resized the new dimensions are allways within the ranges given here. You should take care when setting these options that they do not conflict with the Anchors en Allign settings.

element.name: TBitBtn.Default
element.short: Setting this property will make the OnClick event executed when the user hits ENTER

element.name: TBitBtn.Enabled
element.short: Determines if the button reacts to a click.
element.descr: Setting this property determines if the control can be used. If Enabled is false a bitbutton cannot be clicked. Setting the Enabled property to false also makes its appearance grayed. If an Action has been assigned to the bitbutton and this action is disabled then the enabled property is set to false as well.

element.name: TSpeedButtonActionLink
element.short: Links a TSpeedButton with an action.

element.name: TCustomSpeedButton
element.short: The ancestor class for TSpeedButton
element.descr: TCustomSpeedButton is the ancestor for TSpeedButton. If you want to define your own speedbutton class, you should use this class to derive it from.

element.name: TCustomSpeedButton.Create
element.short: Creates a new instance of the TCustomSpeedButton class
element.descr:
If you drop a component on the form editor you don´t need to add code to explicitly create it. The component is automatically created together with the the form, and destroyed when the form is destroyed.
However, if you create the component by code don´t forget to free it when it is no longer needed.
Constructors allocate memory and system resources needed by the object. They also call the constructor of any sub-objects present in the class.

element.name: TCustomSpeedButton.Destroy
element.short: Deallocates an object
element.descr:
If you call Destroy for an object witch hasn´t being initialized yet it will generate an error. Always use the Free method to deallocate objects, because it verifies if object variable doesn´t contain the value nil.
Take the following precautions when creating your own Destroy method:
* Declare Destroy with the override directive, because it is a virtual method.
* Always call 'inherited Destroy;' as the last thing on the destructor code.
* An exception may be raised on the constructor in case there is not enought memory to create an object, or something else goes wrong. If the exception is not handled inside the constructor, the object will be only partially built. In this case Destroy will be called, so your destructor must check if the resources were really allocated before disposing of them.
* Remember to call Free for all objects created on the constructor.

element.name: TSpeedButton
element.short: A Button used to represent states (checked or not, etc)
element.descr:
The Speed Button is designed to automate a process when it is selected. An user pushes a button to start an action or set a mode.
When a user clicks on a SpeedButton focus is not shifted; a Speed Button never gets focus. The button may carry an descriptive glyph, and has a state (checked or not, etc)

element.name: TSpeedButton.Action
element.short: The action executed when the user clicks the speedbutton.
element.descr: If you assign an action from an ActionList to a TSpeedButton.Action the correspondig execute-method is assigned to the OnClick event of the SpeedButton. Assigning a action sets other properties of the button as well, like Enabled and Caption.

element.name: TSpeedButton.Align
element.short: Is used to align the button to a border of a parent control.
element.descr:
Align is used to align a control to a border of a parent control, even if the parent control is resized.
Possible values fo Allign are:
alTop: Places the control at the top, using the full clientwidth of its parent control.
alBottom: Places the control at the bottom, using the full clientwidth of its parent control.
alLeft: Places the control at the left side of its parent and uses the available height between any top or bottom alligned controls.
alRight: Like alLeft but on the right side of the parent control.
alNone: The control can be placed anywhere on the parent control.
alClient: The control takes al available space on parent control next to controls aligned to the top, bottom, right or left.

element.name: TSpeedButton.AllowAllUp
element.short: Determines wether all speedbuttons in a group can be up.
element.descr: SpeedButtons can be grouped by setting their GroupIndex. AllowAllUp specifies whether or not all SpeedButtons in this group can be unselected (all have the state Up). Changing this property for one SpeedButtons sets this for all SpeedButtons in the same group. A GroupIndex of 0 has no effect, that is AllowAllUp has no effect if GroupIndex is 0.

element.name: TSpeedButton.Caption
element.short: Sets the text displayed on the button.

element.name: TSpeedButton.Down
element.short: Maintains the state of the button.
element.descr: If the groupindex of a SpeedButton is unequal to 0, its state can be up or down. Use this properties to read or set the state of a speedbutton.

element.name: TSpeedButton.Enabled
element.short: Determines if the button reacts to a click.
element.descr:
Setting this property determines if the control can be used. If Enabled is false a speedbutton cannot be clicked. Setting the Enabled property to false also makes its appearance grayed.
If an Action has been assigned to the speedbutton and this action is disabled then the enabled property is set to false as well.

element.name: TSpeedButton.Glyph
element.short: Property to read and set the glyph.

element.name: TSpeedButton.GroupIndex
element.short: Determines how a SpeedButton reacts when it is clicked.
element.descr:
If GroupIndex = 0, the speedbutton reacts like a ordinary push button. That is it appears down when the user clicks on it and it comes up again when the user releases the mouse button.
If GroupIndex > 0, the speedbuttons remains down after the user clicks on it, until it receives a second click.
If more SpeedButtons have the same GroupIndex the behave like a group. You can use SpeedButtons in a group to present mutually exclusive choices to the user. If the user clicks on a SpeedButton in a group, this SpeedButton gets the down state, returning all other buttons to the up state.

element.name: TSpeedButton.Layout
element.short: Determines the place of the glyph with respect to the caption.
element.descr:
Determines the place of the glyph with respect to the caption.
Possible values are:
blGlyphBottom: The glyph is shown under the caption.
blGlyphLeft: The glyph is shown left of the caption.
blGlyphRight: The glyph is shown right of the caption.
blGlyphTop: The glyph is shown above the caption.
